title: Nurse who killed herself on Christmas Eve had been receiving 'threatening messages' on Facebook
text:

A young care nurse who killed herself on Christmas Eve had been receiving threatening messages on Facebook , an inquest heard. 
Kayleigh Caesar, 28, was found hanged in her room at The Dragoon pub in Maidstone oon December 24 last year. 
The court heard how in August last year she witnessed close family friend Paul Robinson being assaulted in the pub which was run by Kayleigh's mum. 
Mr Robinson died two months later - and nobody was subsequently prosecuted in connection to the incident, Kent Police confirmed today. 
Giving evidence at the inquest at Maidstone Coroners' Court, DS Daniel Barker of Kent Police revealed Kayleigh had helped police with their investigation. 
She told officers she had been receiving malicious messages from people connected to the case - which she found upsetting. The Dragoon pub where Kayleigh died - and Paul Robinson was assaulted (Photo: Google Street View) 
Though Kayleigh did not consider her life was at risk, she was advised to keep her phone on her and that CCTV should be improved at the pub, he said. 
There were no signs of third party involvement and notes were found in her room. 
The inquest also heard Kayleigh suffered with mental health issues - and had also had to deal with two bereavements in the run up to her death. 
A post-mortem examination found the cause of death was hanging and tests revealed she had been drinking and had taken cocaine on the day of her death. 
The coroner was told how Kayleigh - who lost her baby Oliver in 2012 - struggled with depression and drink and had previously attempted to take her own life. Kayleigh struggled with mental health issues, the inquest heard (Photo: Facebook) 
Giving a verdict of suicide, assistant coroner Katrina Hepburn said she was satisfied Kayleigh intended to cause her death. 
Her mum, Clare Parslow, said: "We miss Kayleigh every day of our lives and it is not any easier but in life you have to go on no matter what. 
"It is unbelievable how many people truly loved that girl and how many hearts are broken because she couldn't carry on." Read More Teenager killed himself with drug used to knock out elephants that can be absorbed through skin 
She added: "Kayleigh's view of life was simple: Make people happy and help others less fortunate than yourself. 
"To this end she had worked tirelessly over the years in various old people's rest homes offering comfort and help to those in need. 
"Outside of work, she led a social life much of which revolved around The Dragoon public house where she lived. Kayleigh left notes before her death (Photo: Facebook) 
"Her many friends and locals have been touched by her infectious sense of fun with the sound of her laughter never far away. 
"But sometimes the pressures of life can be cruel and a shining star of beauty and goodness has been extinguished. 
"She will be sorely missed but never forgotten by all her family and friends. Rest in peace Kayleigh." Read More 
Nephew Marcus Holness said: "You've left us all in bits Kay, I feel let down by myself I promised you it was us against everything and anyone. 
"You didn't realise how much you meant to us." 
Vikki Baldock said: "Going to miss her so much, feel like my heart is completely broken."
